full_title_en: Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Score with ESR (ASDAS-ESR)
medium_description_en: Stratifies severity of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) using clinical and laboratory data, specifically ESR.

seo.meta_description_en: The Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Score with ESR (ASDAS-ESR) describes severity of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) using clinical and laboratory data, specifically ESR.
seo.keywords_en: Ankylosing spondylitis, disease activity score, AS, ASDAS, ESR, RA, rheumatoid arthritis, disease activity index, DAS28, DAS28-ESR

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: Other than ESR, all values are self-reported by the patient and therefore subjective.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• The ASDAS-CRP is the preferred disease activity index according to the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS), but the ASDAS-ESR may be used as an alternate.

  • May be useful for trending disease activity over time.

next_steps.advice_en: May be useful in helping to guide treatment decisions; e.g. detecting improvement with TNF inhibitors.

about.formula_en:
ASDAS-ESR = (0.08 x back pain) + (0.07 x duration of morning stiffness) + (0.11 x patient global assessment of disease activity) + (0.09 x Peripheral pain/swelling) + (0.29 x √(ESR))

Where variables are:

Back pain

Ask the patient: "How would you describe the overall level of AS neck, back, or hip pain you have had?"

Morning stiffness

Ask the patient: "How would you describe the overall level of morning stiffness you have had from the time you wake up?"

Patient global assessment of disease activity

Ask the patient: "How active was your spondylitis, on average, during the last week?"

Peripheral pain/swelling

Ask the patient: "How would you describe the overall level of pain/swelling in joints other than neck, back, or hips you have had?"

ESR

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate, mm/h

All variables, except ESR, should be graded on a scale of 0 (least severe) to 10 (most severe).

creator_info.about_en: Cédric Lukas, MD, PhD, is an associate professor of rheumatology at University Hospital Lapeyronie in Montpellier, France. He is a member of the EULAR Research Center in Montpellier. Dr. Lukas’ primary research is focused on autoimmune disease, inflammatory disease, and clinical rheumatology.
